text:
KRISTIN FABBE: Looking back
then over your long history

as an entrepreneur and
growing these businesses,

is there any advice that
you wish you had had,

that you would maybe
give to somebody
in your position starting out?

MOHAMMED AL BARWANI:
There's always
things you learn along the way.

And even today, I'm
always learning.

You sit with people
and they give you

the kind of education you may
not get at business schools.

It's kind of from
their own experience

of what they would do, or how
you would structure a deal.

Even at the time when I
bought, I told you JAPEX,
there were only two bidders.

I bid $67 million and the
next bidder bid $14 million.
I knew that in later years.
It made me feel sick.

But later on, I was sitting with
a banker and I was telling him
this is what I bid at.

On the back of an envelope, he
just wrote down the numbers.

He said, this is what
you should have bid at,
more like $45 million.

This is what I like
to tell people.

With all the spreadsheets,
and all the business models,

at the end of the day, you need
just simple gut feeling, logic.

And I'm not the type who will
look at 50 pages of a report.
I can't.

I don't have the
patience for it.

But I like to look at things
which can be put on one page.

I never write a letter
longer than one page.

I never write a report
longer than one page.

And by the same token,
I don't like reading
an email which is five pages.

I'd rather have
somebody read it.

But unfortunately,
a lot of people

go into huge extents
of business modeling,

of building what you call
models, and spreadsheets,

and then believing
what they see there.

But at the end of the day, it's
just you need simple logic.

If you can't calculate something
on two pages, one page,
then it's not worth it.
You shouldn't go into all that.

You should get the key
numbers, the key concepts.
And that's it.

KRISTIN FABBE: So it's
really an intuition,
and simplistic, and--
MOHAMMED AL BARWANI: Simplistic.

You should be able to simply
describe something and simply

put the business model
in a very simple basis,
and explain it simply.

But if it's complicated,
then it's too much.

I always tell my
people, if you're

going to put it on
PowerPoint, make

sure that every page is no
more than three bullet points.

I don't want a PowerPoint
page which is really packed.
It doesn't make sense.

And it should be crystal clear,
easy to understand, and simple.

Unfortunately, you have
people who love and believe
their own models.

KRISTIN FABBE: And obfuscate
things, complicate things.

MOHAMMED AL BARWANI: And
you complicate and then--
what you call--

you are lost in
between the trees.
You don't see the forest.
